Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Robotic-Assisted and Hand-Rasped Techniques in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: randomized to either robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups

Participants.evidence: Participants included 130 patients eligible for primary cementless THA, randomized to either robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups.

Intervention.evidence: randomized to either robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of robotic-assisted versus hand-rasped femoral component insertion in total hip arthroplasty (THA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Japanese Orthopaedic Association (JOA) score, measured at a minimum follow-up of 10 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants included 130 patients eligible for primary cementless THA, randomized to either robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups.

Number_Analysed.evidence: At a mean follow-up of 135 months, 115 patients (88%) were available for analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: JOA scores showed no significant difference between groups (robotic: 97 ± 5, hand-rasped: 96 ± 7; mean difference 1.4; p = 0.159).

Harms.evidence: Heterotopic ossification was observed in 30% of the robotic group and 19% of the hand-rasped group (p = 0.186), with no Grade 4 cases.
